snippet: In one resort town after another, the Republican presidential hopefuls are making their case to exclusive gatherings of donors whose wealth was unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision.
abstract: Prospective Republican presidential candidates are engaged in contest for favor of wealthy donors, in search of money to fund primary campaigns that will decide nominee for 2016; are traveling to cold-weather destinations of the rich whose influence was increased by 2010 Citizens United Supreme Court ruling, allowing them to spend far more than was previously permitted.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and JONATHAN MARTIN
byline.contributor: Nicholas Confessore reported from Palm Beach, and Jonathan Martin from Washington. Maggie Haberman contributed reporting from Washington. Kitty Bennett contributed reporting from Florida.

lead_paragraph: In one resort town after another, the Republican presidential hopefuls are making their case to exclusive gatherings of donors whose wealth was unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision.

headline.main: G.O.P. Race Starts in Lavish Haunts of Rich Donors
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Race Starts in Lavish Haunts of Rich Donors
